content.webTitle: Gascoigne departs Boston and hang up his boots

fields.headline: Gascoigne departs Boston and hangs up his boots
fields.bodyText: Paul Gascoigne's playing career has almost certainly come to an end after the former England midfielder announced yesterday that he was terminating his agreement with Boston United. Gascoigne joined the League Two club as a player-coach in the summer but has struggled to make an impact on the pitch and is now keen to pursue a career in coaching. The 37-year-old said that that he would be leaving York Street with immediate effect and that he hoped to complete an intensive coaching course at Lilleshall. "I've got an opportunity with [the England coach] Sammy Lee coming up," said Gascoigne. "There are no hard feelings between me and Boston - I have left on professional reasons and hopefully they can understand that." Tottenham's chairman Daniel Levy today predicted a bright future for Spurs - despite announcing a loss of £1.189m for the year ended June 30 2004. The club have invested heavily in strengthening the squad and installed a new management structure in the hope of bringing success to White Hart Lane. Spurs' heavy expenditure has been reflected in their accounts, which reveal an operating profit of £9.7m until transfers are included, resulting in an overall loss. However, Levy believes the club are now in a sound position to restore their reputation. "Following a process of change within the club we now have in place a structure that we hope will bring a steady return to the winning performance we all desire for Tottenham Hotspur," he said in a statement to the Stock Exchange. He conceded Spurs could not hope to continue with their current level of expenditure but insisted the outlay on players, which totals £37.5m since July 1 2003, proved that the club are ambitious. Wayne Rooney is one of four Manchester United players nominated for Fifa's World Player of the Year award. Cristiano Ronaldo, Ryan Giggs and Ruud van Nistelrooy are the other United players. Arsenal are represented by Thierry Henry and Robert Pires, and Chelsea's Frank Lampard and Didier Drogba are also among the 35 players listed. Real Madrid, who are represented by Raúl, Luis Figo, Roberto Carlos, Ronaldo, Zinédine Zidane, Michael Owen and David Beckham, are the club with the greatest number of nominations. The winner will be unveiled on December 20. Jonathan Woodgate will wear a Real Madrid shirt for the first time when he faces the third division side Alcorcón in a friendly next week. The England and former Newcastle defender has recently returned to full training. Jay-Jay Okocha has pulled out of Nigeria's World Cup qualifier against Gabon on Saturday, after aggravating a long-standing groin injury at the Hawthorns on Saturday. The midfielder was ordered to play against West Brom by Bolton's manager Sam Allardyce despite asking to miss the match. Richard Dunne will be offered a new contract at Manchester City in January. The former Everton defender was sent home from training by manager Kevin Keegan for "a serious breach of discipline" two years ago but he has since turned his career around and will now be rewarded.
